Fig 4 Theoretical insight of pyrite-like bimetallic diselenides for oxygen reduction reaction Ju-Xia Yi Writing – original draft Investigation a Lei Tao Project administration a ⁎ Yu-Yang Zhang Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ Shi-Xuan Du Project administration Funding acquisition a b a University of Chinese Academy of Sciences and Institute of Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences and Institute of Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China aUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences and Institute of Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China b Songshan Lake Materials Laboratory, Dongguan, Guangdong 523808, China Songshan Lake Materials Laboratory Dongguan Guangdong 523808 China bSongshan Lake Materials Laboratory, Dongguan, Guangdong 523808, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have been widely considered as one of the promising candidates to replace platinum-based oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts due to their attractive properties. However, the single active site in such catalysts poses challenges in surpassing the inherent limits of scaling relations between adsorption energy of multi-intermediates in ORR catalytic process. Herein, inspired by the concept of multiple active centers, we design a series of stable pyrite-like bimetallic diselenides (A0.5B0.5Se2, A = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, B = Cu, Cd, Sn) as catalysts, which aim at enhancing ORR catalytic activity through synergistic effect in dual active sites. Through density functional theory calculations, we find that the ORR activities of most A0.5B0.5Se2 catalysts are comparable to or even better than those of the noble metal Pt, verifying the promotional ORR activities of A0.5B0.5Se2. Among them, Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 has an overpotential of 0.31 V, which shows better catalytic performance than Pt for ORR. Such improvement is attributed to the tandem reaction mechanism and the reduction in the barrier for the rate-determining steps, resulting from the presence of dual active sites within Co0.5Sn0.5Se2. The projected density of states (PDOS) and Bader charge analysis reveal that the excellent catalytic activity is contributed by the strong d-p orbital hybridization between Co and Sn in the Co0.5Sn0.5Se2, which significantly weakens the over-adsorption of the crucial O* intermediates. These findings provide valuable theoretical insights for designing optimum ORR catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pyrite-like bimetallic diselenides Oxygen reduction reaction Dual active sites Tandem catalysis mechanism Synergistic effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The increasing environmental concerns and the global energy crisis due to the depletion of traditional fossil fuels have motivated for searching the sustainable and renewable energy sources [1,2]. Energy technologies such as fuel cells and metal-air batteries are practical, environmentally friendly and efficient solutions in the fields of energy conversion and storage [3–8]. Particularly, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) plays a crucial role in these electrochemical energy technologies [9]. Platinum-based catalysts show excellent ORR performance and have been extensively utilized as electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction. However, the high cost of Pt-based catalysts limits the practical application of these materials on a large scale [9–11]. Given this, a large number of highly active, robust, and cost-effective electrocatalysts free of noble Pt metals have been investigated [12–19]. Among them, transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) are promising candidates due to their earth abundance and robustness. These materials have been widely reported in energy storage [20,21], sensing [22,23], and multifunctional catalysis [24,25]. Moreover, their multiphase structures suggest the potential for tuning catalytic performance [26–33]. For example, hexagonal FeSe (h-FeSe) has been experimentally confirmed to be more efficient than tetragonal FeSe (t-FeSe) towards alkaline ORR [34]. The cubic pyrite phase of TMDs materials as catalysts has also been reported in electrocatalytic reactions. The cases in point are that cubic NiSe2 and CoS2 are experimentally potential ORR catalysts, but their performance still needs to be improved [35,36]. The cubic pyrite CoSe2 has been theoretically predicted to possess the rate-limiting barrier in ORR of 0.43 V, which is comparable to Pt (0.45 V) but not significantly improved [37]. One of the main reasons that limit the catalytic activity is the linear scaling relationships of free energies of intermediates (O*, OH*, and OOH*) at a single active center in ORR catalytic processes, which is difficult to exceed the inherent limit of multi-intermediate reactions due to the lack of synergistic active centers [38]. More importantly, such cubic TMDs catalysts are still far from exhibiting excellent ORR catalytic performance with the sluggish reaction kinetics, mainly because of their relatively strong adsorption for reaction intermediates O* group [37,39]. Therefore, it remains a challenge of designing highly active TMDs catalysts that are capable of achieving top ORR performance. In this paper, motivated by the concept of multiple active centers, we design a series of pyrite-like bimetallic diselenides (A0.5B0.5Se2, A = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, B = Cu, Cd, Sn) to enhance catalytic performance of TMDs materials. Through density functional theory calculations, we systematically investigate the ORR catalytic activities and synergistic effects of all stable A0.5B0.5Se2 electrocatalysts. Our results show that the ORR theoretical overpotentials of A0.5B0.5Se2 are remarkably lower than those of intrinsic ASe2 materials. Among them, the ORR activities of most A0.5B0.5Se2 catalysts are comparable to or even better than those of the noble metal Pt, verifying the excellent ORR performances of A0.5B0.5Se2. Particularly, the Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 catalyst with an overpotential of 0.31 V exhibits the best ORR performance, which is ascribed to the synergistic effect resulting from the presence of dual active sites within Co0.5Sn0.5Se2, leading to a tandem reaction mechanism and a reduction in the barrier for the rate-determining steps. The projected density of states and Bader charge analysis reveal that the enhanced catalytic activity is contributed by the strong d-p orbital hybridization between Co and Sn in the Co0.5Sn0.5Se2, which independently weakens the over-adsorption of the key O* intermediates without affecting the adsorption of OH* and OOH* intermediates. Furthermore, the standard linear scaling relationships between the free energies of three intermediates (ΔG OOH* vs. ΔG OH* and ΔG O* vs. ΔG OH*) in the Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 are successfully established, consequently improving the ORR activity. This theoretical insight provides a valuable guideline to optimize the catalytic activities of ORR catalysts in the future. 2 Computational methods First-principle calculations based on spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) were performed by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [40,41]. The interactions between core electrons and valence electrons were described via the projected-augmented-wave (PAW) method [42]. The exchange-correlation functional was described by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [43]. The Hubbard's U correction scheme was applied with Ueff = 4 eV for transition metal elements (Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) with 3d electrons [44,45]. Using the optimized bulk structures, the most stable (100) surface structures with four layers were constructed and the bottom two layers were fixed in the geometry optimization. A 15 Å vacuum layer was used to eliminate the interactions with the periodic images along the Z-axial direction. The electronic wavefunctions were expanded on a plane wave basis with an energy cutoff of 450 eV. A Γ-centered Monkhorst-Pack k-point sampling of 2 × 2 × 1 was employed for all surface calculations [46]. All atoms were fully relaxed until the energy and residual forces on each atom were smaller than 10−6 eV and 10−2 eV·Å−1, respectively. Bader charge analysis was used to explore the charge change of atoms in all bulk systems [47]. Crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis was performed using the Lobster program [48]. The phonon dispersion was calculated based on a 2 × 2 × 2 supercell using the finite displacement method as implemented in the PHONOPY package [49–51]. The phonon density of states was obtained according to the element type. The Gibbs free energy was calculated by post-processing the VASP-calculated data using the VASPKIT program [52]. Ab initio molecular dynamical simulations (AIMD) were performed under an NVT ensemble with a temperature of 300 K and 400 K for 5 ps [53]. The four-electron transfer reaction pathways of ORR in an acidic medium have been widely investigated, and the four elementary steps can be described by the following equations: (1) * + O 2 + H + + e − → OO H * (2) OO H * + H + + e − → O * + H 2 O (3) O * + H + + e − → O H * (4) O H * + H + + e − → * + H 2 O where * , OO H * , O * , and O H * indicate the adsorption site of the catalyst surface, adsorbed reaction intermediates OOH, O, and OH, respectively. According to the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model suggested by Nørskov et al. [9], the free energy change of each elementary step is calculated at T = 298.15 K, pH = 0, and U = 0 V as the following equation: (5) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S where Δ E is the total energy change obtained from DFT calculations, Δ E ZPE and Δ S represent the zero-point energy and entropy changes, respectively. Since DFT cannot describe the energy of O2 well, the free energy of O2 molecule in the gas phase [9,54] is calculated by (6) G O 2 ( g ) = 2 G H 2 O − 2 G H 2 + 4.92 V The adsorption free energies of three key ORR intermediates (OOH*, O*, and OH*) were calculated as follows (7) Δ G OOH * = G OOH * − G * − 2 G H 2 O + 3 / 2 G H 2 (8) Δ G O * = G O * − G * − G H 2 O + G H 2 (9) Δ G OH * = G OH * − G * − G H 2 O + 1 / 2 G H 2 The overpotential is defined to describe the ORR catalytic activity as shown in the following Eq. (10), and the maximum ΔG among the four elementary steps would determine the reaction rate, that is, the rate-determining step (RDS). (10) η ORR = max [ Δ G 1 , Δ G 2 , Δ G 3 , Δ G 4 ] e + 1.23 V The formation energy of A0.5B0.5Se2 is calculated according to Eq. (11), defined as (11) E form = E A 0.5 B 0.5 S e 2 − 0.5 μ A − 0.5 μ B − 2 μ Se where E A 0.5 B 0.5 S e 2 are the total energies of the A0.5B0.5Se2 systems, μ A , μ B , and μ Se are the chemical potential of A atom, B atom, and Se atom, respectively. It is noted that μ A and μ B are the energies of A and B atoms in the corresponding bulk materials, and μ Se is the energy of a Se atom in the Se8 molecule. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The structures and stabilities of A0.5B0.5Se2 The atomic structure of A0.5B0.5Se2 (A = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, B = Cu, Cd, Sn; for details on the selection of element B see Fig. S1 and Table S1 in the Supplementary Material (SM)) is shown in Fig. 1 (a), where the primitive cell contains four A0.5B0.5Se2 formula units. The A0.5B0.5Se2 adopts a pyrite-like lattice with the P2 1 /c (No. 14) space group. The metal atoms are coordinated to six neighboring selenium atoms. Each selenium atom is coordinated with three metal atoms and one selenium atom, forming a tetrahedron. The calculated magnetic properties of 12 kinds of A0.5B0.5Se2 are represented in Table S2 in the SM. It's worth noting that the magnetic ground states of A0.5B0.5Se2 are all antiferromagnetic, except for the Mn0.5Cu0.5Se2 and Fe0.5Cu0.5Se2. Besides, A0.5Cu0.5Se2 and A0.5Sn0.5Se2 are metallic while all A0.5Cd0.5Se2 are semiconductors. For designing A0.5B0.5Se2 as electrocatalysts, one of the key issues is the structural stability, which can be evaluated by the phonon dispersions, AIMD simulation, formation energy and energy-above-hull analysis. As shown in the Fig. 1(b) and Fig. S2 in the SM, it is found that no imaginary frequencies have been observed in the phonon dispersions of three representative bimetallic A0.5B0.5Se2 (Co0.5Cu0.5Se2, Co0.5Cd0.5Se2 and Co0.5Sn0.5Se2), proving the dynamic stability of A0.5B0.5Se2 catalysts. Moreover, no obvious structural deformation after 300 K and 400 K AIMD simulations for 5 ps (Fig. S3 in the SM), confirming the thermodynamic stability of A0.5B0.5Se2 electrocatalysts. According to Eq. (11) in the SM, the resulting formation energies of all A0.5B0.5Se2 are negative, as displayed in Fig. 1(c), demonstrating their great promise for experimental synthesis. The relevant synthesis methods reported in previous literatures include microwave-assisted polyol process [36], solvothermal process combined with selenization [55], facile precursor transformation method [56] and so on. In addition, the energy-above-hull analysis of two representative A0.5B0.5Se2 such as Co0.5Cd0.5Se2 and Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 in Fig. S4 in the SM further demonstrates the thermal stability of those structures. Moreover, the stability of other AxBySe2 catalysts also have been considered. Taking A0.25B0.75Se2 as an example, the energy-above-hull analysis of Co0.25Cd0.75Se2 and Co0.25Sn0.75Se2 (as shown in the Fig. S4) indicate that they are also thermally stable. 3.2 The catalytical activity and mechanism of A0.5B0.5Se2 According to the Sabatier principle [57], in a multi-step reaction, it's crucial that the adsorption of intermediates onto the catalyst's surface should be at an appropriate level of strength. Hence, based on the interactions between adsorbed oxygenating species and catalytic sites, the synergy of two kinds of metal active sites in the A0.5B0.5Se2 contributes to the transfer of adsorbed intermediates between two active sites. For example, the ORR process on A0.5B0.5Se2 in Fig. 2 (a) represents a classical tandem catalysis mechanism [58–60], which reveals the synergistic effect of the two active sites. In the reaction process, according to the adsorption strength between reaction intermediates (O*, OH*, OOH*) and reaction sites (A and B), the adsorption of O2 and formation of OOH* occur on the A site, and subsequently, the next elementary reactions involving the formation of O* and OH* take place on the B site. This tandem catalysis mechanism, in principle, has weakened the over-bonding of O* species at the A site, thereby enhancing the ORR activity. Fig. 2(b)-(c) show the free energy diagrams of two representative bimetallic A0.5B0.5Se2 (Co0.5Cd0.5Se2 and Co0.5Sn0.5Se2) based on the tandem catalysis mechanism as well as those of ASe2 and BSe2 which only contain single transition metal element. It is found that the rate-determining steps (RDS) of CoSe2, CdSe2 and SnSe2 are O*-OH*, O*-OH* and OH*-H2O, respectively, and corresponding overpotentials are 0.45, 1.09 and 0.70 V, respectively. After optimization of the tandem catalysis mechanism, the RDS of Co0.5Cd0.5Se2 and Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 have been changed to O2-OOH* and OH*-H2O, respectively. And the overpotentials have been significantly reduced to 0.46 and 0.31 V, respectively. The free energy diagrams of other bimetallic A0.5B0.5Se2 are shown in the Fig. S5 in the SM, it is quite clear that the two active sites in the A0.5B0.5Se2 can take effect synergistically to optimize ORR pathway, and the rate-determining steps (RDS) have been adjusted compared with those of the intrinsic ASe2 and BSe2, sequentially accelerating the ORR. Fig. 2(d) summarizes the ORR overpotentials of seven types of monometallic ASe2 and the corresponding 12 bimetallic A0.5B0.5Se2 systems, respectively. The calculated overpotentials of A0.5B0.5Se2 based on the tandem catalysis mechanism are significantly lower than those of intrinsic ASe2 catalysts. Most A0.5B0.5Se2 catalysts have ORR activities that are comparable to or even better than the noble metal Pt. Among them, A0.5Sn0.5Se2 catalysts are remarkably superior to the A0.5Cu0.5Se2 and A0.5Cd0.5Se2. Of course, as long as the two active sites are exposed on the reactive surface, other AxBySe2 catalysts also possess the same excellent catalytic performance as A0.5B0.5Se2. Moreover, the OER and HER activities of A0.5B0.5Se2 as multifunctional catalysts [61,62] also have been considered. As shown in the Table S3, the HER overpotentials of A0.5B0.5Se2 is poor, but the OER overpotentials of Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 catalyst are significantly lower than those of Co0.5Cd0.5Se2 and Co0.5Cu0.5Se2. Among these, Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 catalyst shows an overpotential for OER of 0.65 V and ORR of 0.31 V, indicating its great potential as a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst. 3.3 The linear scaling relationships of A0.5B0.5Se2 It's widely acknowledged that linear scaling relationships exist between the free energies of oxygenating adsorbates (OOH*, O*, and OH*) on most catalysts, demonstrating that the free energies of intermediates are highly correlated with each other [38]. Based on the calculated free energies (Table S4-S7 in the SM), we compare ΔG O* as a function of ΔG OH* as well as ΔG OOH* as a function of ΔG OH* in the ASe2 and A0.5B0.5Se2, as shown in Fig. 3 (a)-(b). The black dotted lines represent the well-known linear scaling relationships, ΔG O* = 2ΔG OH* and ΔG OOH* = ΔG OH* + 3.2, which were proposed by Jens K. Nørskov [38]. It is worth noting that the relationship between ΔG O* and ΔG OH* significantly deviates from the dashed line in Fig. 3(a) because of the over-bonding of O* species in the ASe2, while it undergoes standard relationship in A0.5B0.5Se2. Furthermore, the correlation of ΔG OOH* and ΔG OH* in the ASe2 aligns well with the standard line, and this well-established linear scaling relationship remains in A0.5B0.5Se2. Therefore, the cooperative active sites in the A0.5B0.5Se2 can independently modulate the free energy of O* intermediates without changing the adsorption of OH* and OOH*, consequently enhancing the ORR activity. Given the crucial role that the free energy of O* (ΔG O*) plays in enhancing the ORR activity of A0.5B0.5Se2, larger ΔG O* can lead to lower overpotential (as shown in the Fig. S6(a) in the SM). Therefore, we further search for suitable physical quantities to describe qualitatively ΔG O* [63]. As shown in the Fig. S6 and Table S8 in the SM, it is found that the Pearson correlation coefficient (Pearson's r) between ΔG O*, ionization energy and the number of valence electrons is closest to 1. Particularly, the ionization energy can more intuitively reflect the difficulty of electrons participating in chemical reactions compared with the number of valence electrons. The larger ionization energy makes it difficult for the electrons of metal atoms at the active site to ionize, which subsequently results in the weaker interaction between the O* group and reactive center (larger ΔG O*). As a consequence, the ionization energy of metal atoms at the reaction center can become a feasible descriptor for quantifying the free energy of key O* species. 3.4 The origin of high-performance A0.5B0.5Se2 In order to gain a deep understanding of the synergistic effect contributing to the enhanced ORR performance of A0.5B0.5Se2, we carry out Bader charge analysis to reveal the changes in atomic charge for all systems. Fig. 4 (a) summarizes the numbers of electrons lost at each metal atom in all A0.5B0.5Se2, with the ΔQ e (green sections) representing the variance of the charge of corresponding metal elements in the ASe2 and A0.5B0.5Se2. It is clear that the charge transfer of Sn in the A0.5Sn0.5Se2 is significantly greater than that of SnSe2, indicating a substantial modulation of the electronic states of Sn in A0.5Sn0.5Se2. In contrast, the charge transfer of metal atoms in A0.5Cu0.5Se2 and A0.5Cd0.5Se2 are almost indistinguishable from that in ASe2. This phenomenon has been further verified by the PDOS analysis and electron localization function (ELF), as shown in the Fig. 4(b)-(c) and Fig. S7-S8 in the SM. Taking the PDOS of Co0.5Cd0.5Se2 and Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 as examples (Fig. 4(b)-(c)), the electronic states of Co, Cd atoms in Co0.5Cd0.5Se2 closely resemble those in CoSe2 and CdSe2, while the electronic states of Sn atoms in Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 differ from those in SnSe2. In the Fig. S8, it is found that the electrons in Co0.5Cd0.5Se2 are only localized on Se atoms, while the electrons in Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 are localized on Se atoms and Sn atoms. This indicates that the optimal ORR activity of A0.5Sn0.5Se2 is mainly contributed to the electronic states modulation of Sn induced by the synergistic effect between metal atoms. The interaction between transition-metal atoms in the A0.5B0.5Se2 is investigated by calculating Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) and the integrated COHP (-ICOHP) which is the integration of COHP up to the Fermi level. As shown in Table S9 in the SM, it reveals relatively strong interactions between A and Sn atoms in A0.5Sn0.5Se2. In contrast, the interactions between metal atoms in A0.5Cu0.5Se2 and A0.5Cd0.5Se2 are negligible. Therefore, A0.5Cu0.5Se2 and A0.5Cd0.5Se2 have weak d-d orbital interactions between metal atoms, making them being simple solid solutions with only an ordinary tandem catalysis process for ORR. On the other hand, A0.5Sn0.5Se2 benefits from intense d-p orbital interactions between A and Sn, leading to the modulation of the local electronic structures of Sn. As a result, A0.5Sn0.5Se2 catalysts possess outstanding ORR performance. 4 Conclusions In summary, we provide comprehensive investigations of the ORR catalytic performances of a series of stable A0.5B0.5Se2 electrocatalysts. Our results demonstrate that the ORR activities of most A0.5B0.5Se2 catalysts are comparable to or even exceed those of the noble metal Pt. Particularly, the Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 catalyst with an overpotential of 0.31 V exhibits the best ORR performance. Such enhancement in the ORR electrocatalytic activities is attributed to the tandem catalysis mechanism and strong d-p orbital hybridization between Co and Sn in the Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 catalysts, which significantly weaken the over-binding of the key O* intermediates without affecting the adsorption of OH* and OOH* intermediates. Therefore, this research provides valuable theoretical insights for the design and optimization of ORR catalysts in the future. Appendix A. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have been widely considered as one of the promising candidates to replace platinum-based oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) catalysts due to their attractive properties. However, the single active site in such catalysts poses challenges in surpassing the inherent limits of scaling relations between adsorption energy of multi-intermediates in ORR catalytic process. Herein, inspired by the concept of multiple active centers, we design a series of stable pyrite-like bimetallic diselenides (A0.5B0.5Se2, A = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, B = Cu, Cd, Sn) as catalysts, which aim at enhancing ORR catalytic activity through synergistic effect in dual active sites. Through density functional theory calculations, we find that the ORR activities of most A0.5B0.5Se2 catalysts are comparable to or even better than those of the noble metal Pt, verifying the promotional ORR activities of A0.5B0.5Se2. Among them, Co0.5Sn0.5Se2 has an overpotential of 0.31 V, which shows better catalytic performance than Pt for ORR. Such improvement is attributed to the tandem reaction mechanism and the reduction in the barrier for the rate-determining steps, resulting from the presence of dual active sites within Co0.5Sn0.5Se2. The projected density of states (PDOS) and Bader charge analysis reveal that the excellent catalytic activity is contributed by the strong d-p orbital hybridization between Co and Sn in the Co0.5Sn0.5Se2, which significantly weakens the over-adsorption of the crucial O* intermediates. These findings provide valuable theoretical insights for designing optimum ORR catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical insight of pyrite-like bimetallic diselenides for oxygen reduction reaction
